an1.31-40.en.title: Adantavagga - The Chapter on the Untamed
an1.31-40.en.description: Short teachings on the untamed and the tamed mind.

an1.31-40.pli.title: Adantavagga - The Chapter on the Untamed
an1.31-40.pli.description: Short teachings contrasting the tamed and untamed mind

an1.575-615.en.title: Kāyagatāsativagga - The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
an1.575-615.en.description: Short teachings on the benefits of cultivating mindfulness of the body.

an1.575-615.pli.title: Kāyagatāsativagga - The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
an1.575-615.pli.description: Short teachings on the benefits of cultivating mindfulness of the body

an2.118-129.en.title: Āsāduppajahavagga - Chapter on The Difficult to Abandon
an2.118-129.en.description: Short teachings on contrasting qualities and the way of practice conducive to cultivating an equanimous mind.

an2.118-129.pli.description: Short teachings on contrasting qualities and the way of practice conducive to cultivating an equanimous mind.

an6.74.en.title: Second Discourse on the First Jhāna
an6.74.en.description: Six qualities to abandon to dwell in the first jhāna - 1. thoughts of sensual desire, 2. thoughts of ill-will, 3. thoughts of harm, 4. perception of sensual desire, 5. perception of ill-will, 6. perception of harm.

an6.74.pli.title: Dutiyatajjhānasutta - Second Discourse on the First Jhāna
an6.74.pli.description: Six qualities to abandon to dwell in the first jhāna - 1) thoughts of sensual desire, 2) thoughts of ill-will, 3) thoughts of harm, 4) perception of sensual desire, 5) perception of ill-will, 6) perception of harm.

index.en.title: Introduction
index.en.description: The words of the Buddha is a translation project to translate the Pali canon teachings into English.

index.pli.title: Introduction
index.pli.description: The words of the Buddha is a translation project to translate the Pali canon teachings into English.

mn10.en.title: Establishing of Mindfulness
mn10.en.description: In this teaching, the Buddha shares on establishing the four foundations of mindfulness - body, feelings, mind, and mental qualities. There are six choices for establishing mindfulness of body. There are five different types of mental qualities to be mindful of.
mn10.en.tags: mn,mn1-10,mn1-50,impermanence,meditation,mindfulness,awareness,mindfulness of body,mindfulness of feelings,mindfulness of mind,mindfulness of mental qualities

mn10.pli.title: Satipaṭṭhānasutta - Establishing of Mindfulness
mn10.pli.description: In this teaching, the Buddha shares on establishing the four foundations of mindfulness - body, feelings, mind, and mental qualities.

sn1.1.en.title: Oghataraṇasutta - Crossing the Flood
sn1.1.en.description: The Buddha crossed the flood of suffering without any support and without struggling.

sn1.1.pli.title: Oghataraṇasutta - Crossing the Flood
sn1.1.pli.description: The Buddha crossed the flood of suffering without any support and without struggling.

sn1.2.en.title: Nimokkhasutta - Release
sn1.2.en.description: The Buddha describes how he knows of the release, liberation and independence for living beings.

sn1.2.pli.title: Nimokkhasutta - Release
sn1.2.pli.description: The Buddha describes how he knows of the release, liberation and independence for living beings.

sn1.3.en.title: Upanīyasutta - The Short Life
sn1.3.en.description: For one brought to old age, there are no shelters

sn1.3.pli.title: Upanīyasutta - The Short Life
sn1.3.pli.description: For one brought to old age, there are no shelters

sn3.13.en.title: Doṇapākasutta - A Bucket Of Rice
sn3.13.en.description: The Buddha observes the King Pasenadi as huffing and puffing and advises him on moderation in eating.

sn3.13.pli.title: Doṇapākasutta - A Bucket Of Rice
sn3.13.pli.description: The Buddha observes the King Pasenadi as huffing and puffing and advises him on moderation in eating.

sn3.4.en.title: Piyasutta - Dear
sn3.4.en.description: One who engages in good conduct by body, speech, and mind is dear to themselves.

sn3.4.pli.title: Piyasutta - Dear
sn3.4.pli.description: One who engages in good conduct by body, speech, and mind is dear to themselves.

sn7.2.en.title: Akkosasutta - Insult
sn7.2.en.description: A brahmin approaches the Buddha and abuses and insults him. The Buddha doesn't accept it, and explains this to the brahmin through a simile.

sn7.2.pli.title: Akkosasutta - Insult
sn7.2.pli.description: A brahmin approaches the Buddha and abuses and insults him. The Buddha doesn't accept it, and explains this to the brahmin through a simile.

sn14.15.en.title: Walking Back and Forth
sn14.15.en.description: In this teaching, the Buddha is addressing on how beings come together and associate based on dispositions and intent.

sn14.15.pli.title: Caṅkamasutta - Walking Back and Forth
sn14.15.pli.description: In this teaching, the Buddha is sharing how beings come together and associate based on shared qualities and traits.

sn56.38.en.title: Second Discourse on the Sun
sn56.38.en.description: As long as sun and moon do not arise in the world, there is complete darkness. Similarly, as long as the Buddha has not arisen in the world, there is complete darkness, dense darkness.

sn56.38.pli.title: Dutiyasūriyasutta - Second Discourse on the Sun
sn56.38.pli.description: As long as sun and moon do not arise in the world, there is complete darkness. Similarly, as long as the Buddha has not arisen in the world, there is complete darkness, dense darkness.

snp1.8.en.title: Loving-kindness
snp1.8.en.description: Verses on the way of practice to peace through the cultivation of loving-kindness for all beings without an exception and at all times whether one is standing, walking, sitting, or lying down.

snp4.1.en.title: Desires
snp4.1.en.description: In this teaching, the Buddha is succintly sharing the allure and the drawbacks of desiring pleasure.

snp4.15.en.title: Fear arises from harm
snp4.15.en.description: The Buddha shares in poignant terms his observations on the agitation all beings experience which led to his urgency to awaken. He then shares on the path to awakening and describes the dwelling of an awakened being.

snp4.15.pli.title: Attadaṇḍasutta - Fear arises from harm
snp4.15.pli.description: The Buddha shares in poignant terms his observations on the agitation all beings experience which led to his urgency to awaken. He then shares on the path to awakening and describes the dwelling of an awakened being.

snp4.2.en.title: Cave
snp4.2.en.description: Eight verses on overcoming the mire of delusion by avoiding attachment to sensory pleasures, discerning their causes, and practicing for being free of 'mine'.

ud2.3.en.title: On stick
ud2.3.en.description: Inspired utterance on bodily conduct and one's own happiness

ud2.3.pli.title: Daṇḍasutta - On Stick
ud2.3.pli.description: Inspired utterance on bodily conduct and one's own happiness

ud2.4.en.title: On Honor
ud2.4.en.description: Inspired utterance on dealing with insult and abuse. The
